metadata.abstract: Influenza viruses with multiple subtypes have highly virulent in humans, of which influenza hemagglutinin (HA) is the major viral surface antigen. Simultaneous and automated detection of multiple influenza HA are of great importance for early-stage diagnosis and operator protection. Herein, a magnetism and size mediated microfluidic platform was developed for point-of-care detection of multiple influenza HA. With multiplex microvalves and computer program control, the detection process showed high automation which had a great potential for avoiding the high-risk virus exposure to the operator. Taking advantage of magnetism and size mediated multiple physical fields, multiple influenza HA could be simultaneous separation and detection depended on different-size magnetic beads. Using high-luminance quantum dots as reporter, this assay achieved high sensitivity with a detection limit of 3.4 ng/mL for H7N9 HA and 4.5 ng/mL for H9N2 HA, and showed excellent specificity, anti-interference ability and good reproducibility. These results indicate that this method may propose new avenues for early detection of multiple influenza subtypes.

Zefen Zhang is currently a master student at school of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, Wuhan Textile University, China. Her research is focused on the magnetism-controlled microfluidic device, virus detection and biological medical equipment.

Tang Man received her Ph.D. degree from College of Chemistry and Molecular Science in Wuhan University, China, in the year of 2018. Her main research interest includes microfluidic device design and application, magnetic nanomaterials and circulating tumor cells.

Zhang Nangang received his Ph.D. degree from School of Physics and Technology in Wuhan University, China, in the year of 2012. He is currently a associate professor in School of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, Wuhan Textile University, China. His main research interest includes microfluidic chip, biological nanomaterial preparation and application, tumor diagnosis technology and biomedicine equipment.

Liu Feng received his master degree in School of Electronic Information and Communications, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, China, in the year of 2009. He is now working as a laboratory technician in School of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, Wuhan Textile University, China. His main research is focus on the study of embedded system design and Internet of things (IoT) technology.

Gujing Han received her Ph.D. degree in Wuhan University, China, in the year of 2008. She is currently a associate professor in School of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, Wuhan Textile University, China. Her main research interest in electric control.

Hong Shaoli received his Ph.D. degree from College of Chemistry and Molecular Science in Wuhan University, China, in the year of 2018. He is currently a lecturer in School of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, Wuhan Textile University, China. His main research interest includes magnetism-controlled microfluidic device, virus detection and aptamer selection.

Liu Kan received his Ph.D. degree from School of Physics and Technology in Wuhan University, China, in the year of 2007. Then he did postdoctoral research at Department of Molecular and Medical Pharmacology and California Nanosystems Institute (CNSI), University of California, Los Angeles, between 2007 and 2010. He is now a professor at School of Electronic and Electrical Engineering in Wuhan Textile University and School of Life Science and Technology in the University of Electronic Science and Technology of China. His current research areas include microfluidic chip development and its application in biomedical research and chemical synthesis, ultra-micro sample online processing, large-scale integrated valve-controlled microfluidic chip and its digital automatic control.
